engine.audio

Interface IAudioDevice

  • All Known Implementing Classes:
    OpenALAudioDevice

    public interface IAudioDevice
    Interface for some piece of hardware, physical or virtual, that is capable of playing audio.
    Author:
    Benny Bobaganoosh (thebennybox@gmail.com)

    • Field Summary

      Fields 
      Modifier and Type Field and Description

    • Method Detail

      • dispose

        void dispose()
        Releases any resources being used. Should not be used after this is called.

      • createAudioData

        int createAudioData(byte[] data,
                  int format,
                  int sampleRate,
                  boolean isBigEndian)
        Creates a piece of audio data that can be used by this audio device. It is preferred to use this through the SoundData class when possible.
        Parameters:
        data - The raw array of bytes specifying the piece of audio.
        format - The format of data. Should be one of the IAudioDevice.FORMAT options.
        sampleRate - The number of samples data specifies per second of audio.
        isBigEndian - True if data is in big endian byte ordering; false otherwise.
        Returns:
        An integer identifying this audio data on this device.

      • releaseAudioData

        int releaseAudioData(int dataId)
        Releases and invalidates a piece of audio. The value of dataId will be invalid after this call and may be reused to identify a new piece of audio. Note that this does nothing when the null id, 0, is given for dataId.

        It is preferred to use this through the SoundData class when possible.

        Parameters:
        dataId - The integer identifying the audio data to be released.
        Returns:
        The null dataId of 0.

      • createAudioObject

        int createAudioObject(int dataId,
                    double volume,
                    double pitch,
                    boolean shouldLoop)
        Creates an audio object that completely specifies a playable piece of sound. It is preferred to use this through the Sound class when possible.
        Parameters:
        dataId - The integer that identifies the audio data being played.
        volume - How loud the audio should be played at. 1.0 specifies normal volume, and lower or higher values specify quieter or louder volumes, respectively.

        If the device is incapable of playing audio at the specified volume, then the audio should be played at the closest possible volume to the volume specified.

        pitch - What pitch the audio should be played at. 1.0 specifies normal pitch, and lower or higher values specify higher or lower pitches, respectively.

        If the device is incapable of playing audio at the specified pitch, then the audio should be played at the closest possible pitch to the pitch specified.

        shouldLoop - Whether the audio should automatically restart when finished playing.
        Returns:
        An integer identifying this audio object on the device.

      • updateAudioObject

        void updateAudioObject(int objectId,
                     double volume,
                     double pitch,
                     boolean shouldLoop)
        Updates an existing audio object with new parameters. It is preferred to use this through the Sound class when possible.
        Parameters:
        objectId - The integer that identifies the audio object being updated.
        volume - How loud the audio should be played at. 1.0 specifies normal volume, and lower or higher values specify quieter or louder volumes, respectively.

        If the device is incapable of playing audio at the specified volume, then the audio should be played at the closest possible volume to the volume specified.

        pitch - What pitch the audio should be played at. 1.0 specifies normal pitch, and lower or higher values specify higher or lower pitches, respectively.

        If the device is incapable of playing audio at the specified pitch, then the audio should be played at the closest possible pitch to the pitch specified.

        shouldLoop - Whether the audio should automatically restart when finished playing.

      • releaseAudioObject

        int releaseAudioObject(int objectId)
        Releases and invalidates an audio object. The value of objectId will be invalid after this call and may be reused to identify a new audio object. Note that this does nothing when the null id, 0, is given for objectId.

        It is preferred to use this through the Sound class when possible.

        Parameters:
        objectId - The integer identifying the audio object to be released.
        Returns:
        The null objectId of 0.

      • play

        void play(int objectId)
        Plays an audio object through this audio device. If it is already playing, it is stopped and restarted. When the audio is finished playing, it will stop if the object's shouldLoop is false, or it will restart if the object's shouldLoop is true. It is preferred to use this through the Sound class when possible.
        Parameters:
        objectId - The integer identifying the audio object to be played.

      • stop

        void stop(int objectId)
        Stops playing an audio object through this device and resets its position to the start of the audio. When the object is played again, it should start at the beginning. It is preferred to use this through the Sound class when possible.
        Parameters:
        objectId - The integer identifying the audio object to be stopped.

      • pause

        void pause(int objectId)
        Stops playing an audio object through this device, but leaves it's position alone. When the object is played again, it should start where it left off. It is preferred to use this through the Sound class when possible.
        Parameters:
        objectId - The integer identifying the audio object to be paused.
